posts.name: Jac
posts.cooked:
If the payment options (at least in Android) can be‚Ä¶

  1. non-google pay based (other payment options are for donations only)
  2. flexible - ¬£4/$5 per month is the minimum

‚Ä¶I would do this straight away. I noticed there is anonymity tied to this feature and may be the reason for this but personally I have no problem Signal being aware of my number and a donation, as long as nothing is exposed publicly.

At the moment I am making regular donations as I want to remove my dependency and use of google pay. Also, Singal is great and I think $5 is justified, however many other core security minded open-source services (e.g. protonmail, bitwarden) that have free and paying customers begin at $1-2 so I think many more people would become a sustainer if the minimum was lower.

link_counts.title: Why are there so few choices for monthly donations?

posts.cooked: On a Dutch computer forum I have read several complaints about ‚Ç¨5/mo being the lowest possible amount as well. ‚Ç¨2/mo for a meteor or comet dust badge perhaps?
the website supports more options and custom amounts. parity inside the app would be nice.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
They confirmed more payment options are coming in the future in the recent blog post:

Signal Messenger

Become a Signal Sustainer

Signal has no data to sell, no advertisers to sell it to, and no shareholders to benefit from such a sale. We‚Äôre building a different kind of tech ‚Äì where your data stays in your hands ‚Äì but we‚Äôre also building a different kind of tech organization....

link_counts.title: Signal >> Blog >> Become a Signal Sustainer

posts.cooked: I second this request! I would be happy to pay 2 Euros a month. I don‚Äôt care about google pay though, and even less to have some unnecessary sustainer batch.
Then you could just donate using PayPal, I suppose.

I can‚Äôt donate to Signal from my country using PayPal. The ‚ÄúSignal Technology Foundation‚Äù, that is not found on Signal‚Äôs website, but through googling ‚Äúsignal donate paypal‚Äù is not available from my European country. On the website I saw the donorbox, but that is only 3 USD and more. I think it would be beneficial if donations of small amounts are easier. I‚Äôm sure many more users would subscribe, especially if it‚Äôs easily done through the android or ios app, as is the case for the >5 USD sustainer option.

fgerick:

I think it would be beneficial if donations of small amounts are easier.

All donations (no matter if through the website or the app) will cost the signal foundation a process fee by the payment service. This makes small donations unpractical. As the fee is sometimes a fixed amount per transaction (not a percentage) it may also cost signal money to accept small donations.
Like imagine the fee being 1$ per Transaction but you only want to donate 50 cents .
I see, I didn‚Äôt take the fees into consideration. I guess I will just do a one time donation then and hopefully remember again next year! Thanks for clarifying

posts.name: Jac
posts.cooked: Good point about transaction fees, however donate annually as an option would fix this e.g. $12/24 so one transaction but effectively $1/2 per month. Bitwarden charge like this.
That‚Äôs odd. From my country it worked fine in EUR.

It should be a high priority to add new payment options. The more that are offered, the more people can participate.
For example, I don‚Äôt have a credit card and I‚Äôm not going to get one. (Honestly, I don‚Äôt even know why this ‚Äútechnology‚Äù still has a place in the 21st century, but that‚Äôs off-topic).
That announcement was 1.5 month ago, are there any news what additional methods is being worked on and how long it‚Äôll take?

And I also can agree with 5/10/20‚Ç¨ per month is a bit much for a single user. If fees are the problem here‚Ä¶ still see above. Add payment methods which are not affected by high fees. There are also cryptocurrencies with that advantage. Afaik XLM and ADA have kinda low and e.g. IOTA has no fees at all.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: There are more payment options if you donate via the website: Signal >> Donate to Signal Private Messenger.

MrWinstonSmith84:

I think many more people would become a sustainer if the minimum was lower.

Having a lower minimum might lower the threshold to become a sustainer and therefore increase the overall number of sustainers, but at the same time, it could also result in a smaller number of sustainers who would otherwise have donated the current minimum. The million dollar question is whether lowering the minimum sustainer amount would actually result in a net increase in the overall amount of donated money.

For every existing sustainer who switches from the current minimum to the new minimum, there would need to be several new users who would be willing to become sustainers for the first time. The current minimum sustainer amount that Signal has settled on may be a compromise that maximizes their revenue, and lowering it might result in a net loss.

posts.name: Fredrik Blomqvist
posts.cooked:
I mean if money was their only objective they could just kill the donation feature entirely and just put their effort into talking ultra-wealthy donors that could provide for the entire platform?

I see the donation possibilities more-so as a way to foster a sustainable future where the platform is sustained by as many as possible rather than by the minority. It‚Äôs also a good way to foster an understanding of the fact that there‚Äôs not always some very wealthy person that will pay for you.

posts.name: Jac
posts.cooked: True. However, donations and sustainers are doing it voluntarily (and currently not prompted to do this, I had to actively seek to donate) so I suspect they would donate the same despite the options, rather than the typical customer behaviour of what is the cheapest option for the product I am receiving. UI helps here also, suggesting set amounts to attract the desired investment (e.g. $3, $5, $7) followed by a custom option with whatever the minimum is (e.g. $1). Paying monthly or annually also provides flexibility so someone can choose a set amount e.g. $20, $50 for the year, rather than multiples of 12.

posts.name: Joe Hardi
posts.cooked:
Been using signal the past year and convinced a lot of friends to join.

As Signal just launched the substainer programm, I was absolutely willed to contribute on a monthly basis.

But I saw that the only possibility is to pay via Google Pay right now‚Ä¶ Besides the fact that I am using Signal exactly to avoid Google and the rest, I am also running e/OS/ (Murena) with MicroG with litteraly doesn‚Äôt allow me to continue.

Are there any planes to introduce different donation options? It feels a bit strange to me that this seems to be the only option.

Edit: Thanks for the all the responses! Actually I really like to get the badge when donating via the app - not because to show off but to convince or animate others to do the same. Signal really is a big thing in the fight for privacy.

posts.name: Nate
posts.cooked:
Apple Pay is non existent in India. Because of which I can‚Äôt donate to signal from my iPhone. The workaround would be to donate from the web, which im okay with, but the fact that you guys can‚Äôt give me my badge is a bummer.

Can you please do a workaround wherein you can give the users their badges even if they donate via the website?

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
nateavi:

Can you please do a workaround wherein you can give the users their badges even if they donate via the website?

This would mean tying accounts to donations which nobody wants.

posts.name: Nate
posts.cooked: Fair point. But how about making it optional? The donors get to choose if they go down the fully private route, or get the badges.
